elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new coordination polymer, [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(atz)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(PTA)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> has been firstly synthesized by employing mixed-ligand of terephthalic acid (PTA) with the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate (atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> represents a 3D microporous framework constructed from Cd-tetrazolate subunits and the subunits are bridged by PTA and atz ligands. When the subunit was collided into node, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses an unprecedented 3, 9-connected topological network. Furthermore, the investigations of thermal stability and luminescent property of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicate that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be an excellent candidate for potential blue-light emitting material.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new coordination polymer, [Cd4(atz)6(PTA)] n  has been firstly synthesized by employing mixed-ligand of terephthalic acid (PTA) with the in-situ generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate (atz-). Compound 1 represents a 3D microporous framework constructed from Cd-tetrazolate subunits and the subunits are bridged by PTA and atz ligands. When the subunit was collided into node, compound 1 possesses an unprecedented 3, 9-connected topological network. Furthermore, the investigations of thermal stability and luminescent property of complex 1 indicate that compound 1 may be an excellent candidate for potential blue-light emitting material.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new coordination polymer, [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(atz)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(PTA)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> has been firstly synthesized by employing mixed-ligand synthetic approach. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a 3D microporous framework with an unprecedented 3, 9-connected topological network.<ce:display>
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new coordination polymer, [Cd4(atz)6(PTA)] n  has been firstly synthesized by employing mixed-ligand synthetic approach. Compound 1 presents a 3D microporous framework with an unprecedented 3, 9-connected topological network.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Metal–organic framework (MOF) coordination polymers have attracted great attention for their potential applications as functional materials . Recently, tetrazole chemistry, a new research field, has developed rapidly and become very popular in many areas due to its applications in medicinal chemistry and advanced materials science . From the coordination chemistry point of view, the tetrazolate group has good coordination ability not only because its acidity is close to the carboxylate group, but because its multiple N-donor atoms exhibit versatile bridging modes as well. Numerous metal–organic coordination compounds constructed from tetrazole-based ligand have been reported, such as the low-dimensional structures of transition metal complexes of 1-substituted tetrazole (1-R-tetrazoles), R<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>alkyl , phenyl , chloroethyl  and methoxyethyl  etc.. Since the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> method was first proposed and successfully applied to preparing an unexpected compound by Champness and Schröder in 1997 , of particular interest, Xiong et al. borrowed Sharpless' idea  and prepared a series of tetrazole-based multi-dimensional coordination polymers with intriguing variety of architectures, topologies and new properties by the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> synthesis of tetrazole from various nitrile with azide . In order to get coordination polymers with more fascinating architectures and topologies, mix-ligand was introduced in the prepared systems by design. Some mixed-ligand MOFs with unique 3D architectures or 2-fold interpenetrating layered networks  based on triazolate-system and carboxylate species have been constructed. These results reveal that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is reliable to achieve unusual MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic framework (MOF) coordination polymers have attracted great attention for their potential applications as functional materials . Recently, tetrazole chemistry, a new research field, has developed rapidly and become very popular in many areas due to its applications in medicinal chemistry and advanced materials science . From the coordination chemistry point of view, the tetrazolate group has good coordination ability not only because its acidity is close to the carboxylate group, but because its multiple N-donor atoms exhibit versatile bridging modes as well. Numerous metal-organic coordination compounds constructed from tetrazole-based ligand have been reported, such as the low-dimensional structures of transition metal complexes of 1-substituted tetrazole (1-R-tetrazoles), R=alkyl , phenyl , chloroethyl  and methoxyethyl  etc.. Since the in-situ method was first proposed and successfully applied to preparing an unexpected compound by Champness and Schröder in 1997 , of particular interest, Xiong et al. borrowed Sharpless' idea  and prepared a series of tetrazole-based multi-dimensional coordination polymers with intriguing variety of architectures, topologies and new properties by the in-situ synthesis of tetrazole from various nitrile with azide . In order to get coordination polymers with more fascinating architectures and topologies, mix-ligand was introduced in the prepared systems by design. Some mixed-ligand MOFs with unique 3D architectures or 2-fold interpenetrating layered networks  based on triazolate-system and carboxylate species have been constructed. These results reveal that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is reliable to achieve unusual MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">5-Amino-tetrazolate, as a multifunctional tetrazole derivative, has five binding sites (one amino group and four amino-nitrogen atoms). It has been used to construct some interesting MOFs from the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> generated or available atz ligand . Terephthalic acid (PTA), as a good multidentate bridging ligand, has been widely used to construct MOFs because it can form short bridges via one carboxylato end or long bridges via the benzene ring, leading a great variety of structures . While compared with those reported metal–tetrazolate cases, mixed-ligand coordination complexes with tetrazole and carboxylic acid ligands are still rarely presented up to now. As a part of our ongoing study on the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> generated Hatz ligand based on coordination polymers , a new microporous coordination polymer of [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(atz)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(PTA)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was obtained from hydrothermal reactions of CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, dicyandiamide, PTA and distilled water at 165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days . The crystalline phase purity was confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the bulk solid (), and the compositions were further defined from single crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis. Additionally, the thermal stability and photoluminescence behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were also investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 5-Amino-tetrazolate, as a multifunctional tetrazole derivative, has five binding sites (one amino group and four amino-nitrogen atoms). It has been used to construct some interesting MOFs from the in-situ generated or available atz ligand . Terephthalic acid (PTA), as a good multidentate bridging ligand, has been widely used to construct MOFs because it can form short bridges via one carboxylato end or long bridges via the benzene ring, leading a great variety of structures . While compared with those reported metal-tetrazolate cases, mixed-ligand coordination complexes with tetrazole and carboxylic acid ligands are still rarely presented up to now. As a part of our ongoing study on the in-situ generated Hatz ligand based on coordination polymers , a new microporous coordination polymer of [Cd4(atz)6(PTA)] n  (1) was obtained from hydrothermal reactions of CdCl2, NaN3, dicyandiamide, PTA and distilled water at 165°C for 3days . The crystalline phase purity was confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the bulk solid (), and the compositions were further defined from single crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis. Additionally, the thermal stability and photoluminescence behavior of 1 were also investigated.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Single crystal X-ray analysis  shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a microporous 3D framework. It crystallizes in tetragonal space group <ce:italic>I-4c2</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains one crystallographically independent Cd(II) atom, one and a half atz ligands, and half of a PTA ligand, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd center lies on the general position and coordinates with five nitrogen atoms from five atz ligands and one oxygen atom from the one PTA ligand to form a significantly distorted octahedron. Four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2(ii), N5(iii) and N4 from four atz ligands, respectively) define an equatorial quasi-plane, and the axial positions are completed by one oxygen atom from a PTA ligand and one nitrogen atom (N2(i)) from the sixth atz ligand for Cd center to form a distorted octahedron. The bond distances of Cd–N and Cd–O are 2.331(3)–2.451(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å and 2.286(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, which are well in the range of the values of those reported Cd(II) compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray analysis  shows that 1 is a microporous 3D framework. It crystallizes in tetragonal space group I-4c2. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Cd(II) atom, one and a half atz ligands, and half of a PTA ligand, respectively ( ). The Cd center lies on the general position and coordinates with five nitrogen atoms from five atz ligands and one oxygen atom from the one PTA ligand to form a significantly distorted octahedron. Four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2(ii), N5(iii) and N4 from four atz ligands, respectively) define an equatorial quasi-plane, and the axial positions are completed by one oxygen atom from a PTA ligand and one nitrogen atom (N2(i)) from the sixth atz ligand for Cd center to form a distorted octahedron. The bond distances of Cd-N and Cd-O are 2.331(3)-2.451(3)Å and 2.286(2)Å, respectively, which are well in the range of the values of those reported Cd(II) compounds .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the symmetry-related Cd1 atoms are bridged by two pairs of N atoms from two atz ligands and a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>:η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-carboxylato group to form Cd-dimer subunit. The neighboring subunits are fused by three pairs of N atoms from one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>- and two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-atz ligands to generate a corrugation strip along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis direction, and the carboxylato groups lay on the two sides of the strip (a<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). At the same time, each <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-atz ligand, which is linked to the Cd-dimer, associated with the third <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-atz ligand to connect four adjacent strips in four different directions to form a 3D porous framework (b). It is noteworthy that the 3D porous framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains two kinds of 1D channel (channels A and B, ). The size of the rhombus channel A is about 6.53<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6.53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, and the inner surface of the rhombus channel is decorated with amino groups of atz ligands, resulting in a hydrophilic channel. For channel B, the size of the channel is big enough and the inner surface of the channel is not only decorated with amino groups of atz ligands, but also supported by the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>–<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>:η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>:η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>:η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> of PTA ligand. Compared with the other Cd(II) tetrazolate , the size of the void was effectively enhanced when the second ligand, PTA, was introduced to the metal–tetrazolate system. Large void of channel B resulted in the disorder of phenylene rings when no other solvent molecules were filled in the voids. A total potential solvent accessible volume of 16.5% for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was calculated using PLATON . The 3D porous framework structure is further stabilized by the weak N–H…O hydrogen bonding interactions (N7–H1…O1(#1), 3.326<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the amino groups donating H atoms to the carboxylate oxygen atoms, and N–H…N hydrogen bonding interactions (N3–H3…N8(#2), 3.030<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the amino groups donating H atoms to the tetrazole N atoms. (Symmetry generated code: #1, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1/2, <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1/2; #2, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1/2, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1/2.)</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In compound 1, the symmetry-related Cd1 atoms are bridged by two pairs of N atoms from two atz ligands and a μ 2, η 1 :η 1-carboxylato group to form Cd-dimer subunit. The neighboring subunits are fused by three pairs of N atoms from one μ 4- and two μ 3-atz ligands to generate a corrugation strip along the c-axis direction, and the carboxylato groups lay on the two sides of the strip (a). At the same time, each μ 3-atz ligand, which is linked to the Cd-dimer, associated with the third μ 3-atz ligand to connect four adjacent strips in four different directions to form a 3D porous framework (b). It is noteworthy that the 3D porous framework of 1 contains two kinds of 1D channel (channels A and B, ). The size of the rhombus channel A is about 6.53×6.53Å2, and the inner surface of the rhombus channel is decorated with amino groups of atz ligands, resulting in a hydrophilic channel. For channel B, the size of the channel is big enough and the inner surface of the channel is not only decorated with amino groups of atz ligands, but also supported by the μ 4-η 1 :η 1 :η 1 :η 1 of PTA ligand. Compared with the other Cd(II) tetrazolate , the size of the void was effectively enhanced when the second ligand, PTA, was introduced to the metal-tetrazolate system. Large void of channel B resulted in the disorder of phenylene rings when no other solvent molecules were filled in the voids. A total potential solvent accessible volume of 16.5% for compound 1 was calculated using PLATON . The 3D porous framework structure is further stabilized by the weak N-H…O hydrogen bonding interactions (N7-H1…O1(#1), 3.326Å), via the amino groups donating H atoms to the carboxylate oxygen atoms, and N-H…N hydrogen bonding interactions (N3-H3…N8(#2), 3.030Å), via the amino groups donating H atoms to the tetrazole N atoms. (Symmetry generated code: #1, - y +1/2, x -1/2, - z +1/2; #2, - x +1/2, - y +1/2, z +1/2.)

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Topologically, when the Cd-dimer subunit is collided into one node, which connects nine other same nodes through six <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-atz ligands, two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-atz ligands and PTA linker, the collided-node can be viewed as a 9-connected node. The <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-atz ligand links three collided-nodes, so it can be regarded as a 3-connected node (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). Based on this simplification, the quite complicated 3D network of 1 can be presented as an unprecedented (3, 9)-connected topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>) with the Schläfli vertex symbol  of (3·5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·7<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Topologically, when the Cd-dimer subunit is collided into one node, which connects nine other same nodes through six μ 3-atz ligands, two μ 4-atz ligands and PTA linker, the collided-node can be viewed as a 9-connected node. The μ 3-atz ligand links three collided-nodes, so it can be regarded as a 3-connected node ( ). Based on this simplification, the quite complicated 3D network of 1 can be presented as an unprecedented (3, 9)-connected topology ( ) with the Schläfli vertex symbol  of (3⋅52)(34⋅42⋅513⋅610⋅77).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is air stable and insoluble in common inorganic or organic solvents. The plot DSC and TG curves together () indicate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 360<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>°C, and then the framework collapses corresponding to the removal of the organic atz and PTA ligands. Microporous coordination polymer with such high thermal stability is rarely observed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 is air stable and insoluble in common inorganic or organic solvents. The plot DSC and TG curves together () indicate that 1 is stable up to 360°C, and then the framework collapses corresponding to the removal of the organic atz and PTA ligands. Microporous coordination polymer with such high thermal stability is rarely observed.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is well known that coordination polymers with a d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration metal possess excellent luminescence property . Herein, the solid-state fluorescent property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, the intensely strong blue-fluorescent emission bands are observed at 455 and 505<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, the free Hatz ligand and PTA ligand present photoluminescence emissions at 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 387<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, according to the reported literature . Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be tentatively attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transition (MLCT) and/or ligand-to-metal charge transition(LMCT), which has been observed in other tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymers . Along with the high thermal stability and insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the emission in the blue region makes this compound a potential blue-light emitting material.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is well known that coordination polymers with a d10 configuration metal possess excellent luminescence property . Herein, the solid-state fluorescent property of compound 1 was investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at λ ex =360nm, the intensely strong blue-fluorescent emission bands are observed at 455 and 505nm for 1. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480nm, the free Hatz ligand and PTA ligand present photoluminescence emissions at 325nm and 387nm, respectively, according to the reported literature . Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may be tentatively attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transition (MLCT) and/or ligand-to-metal charge transition(LMCT), which has been observed in other tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymers . Along with the high thermal stability and insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the emission in the blue region makes this compound a potential blue-light emitting material.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, a new microporous Cadmium coordination polymer with high thermal stability and intense luminescence emission has been successfully prepared when mixed-ligands terephthalate and the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> generated 5-amino-tetrazolate were applied under hydrothermal conditions. Topologically, compound 1 possesses an unprecedented (3, 9)-connected topology net with the Schläfli symbol of (3·5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·7<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>). This result reveals that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is viable to achieve unusual MOFs with some unprecedented topological nets in tetrazole-based system.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a new microporous Cadmium coordination polymer with high thermal stability and intense luminescence emission has been successfully prepared when mixed-ligands terephthalate and the in-situ generated 5-amino-tetrazolate were applied under hydrothermal conditions. Topologically, compound 1 possesses an unprecedented (3, 9)-connected topology net with the Schläfli symbol of (3⋅52)(34⋅42⋅513⋅610⋅77). This result reveals that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is viable to achieve unusual MOFs with some unprecedented topological nets in tetrazole-based system.

Supplementary data

CCDC 722565 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Supplementary material associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2010.03.041.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is air stable and insoluble in common inorganic or organic solvents. The plot DSC and TG curves together () indicate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 360<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>°C, and then the framework collapses corresponding to the removal of the organic atz and PTA ligands. Microporous coordination polymer with such high thermal stability is rarely observed.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">It is well known that coordination polymers with a d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration metal possess excellent luminescence property . Herein, the solid-state fluorescent property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, the intensely strong blue-fluorescent emission bands are observed at 455 and 505<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, the free Hatz ligand and PTA ligand present photoluminescence emissions at 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 387<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, according to the reported literature . Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be tentatively attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transition (MLCT) and/or ligand-to-metal charge transition(LMCT), which has been observed in other tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymers . Along with the high thermal stability and insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the emission in the blue region makes this compound a potential blue-light emitting material.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Compound 1 is air stable and insoluble in common inorganic or organic solvents. The plot DSC and TG curves together () indicate that 1 is stable up to 360°C, and then the framework collapses corresponding to the removal of the organic atz and PTA ligands. Microporous coordination polymer with such high thermal stability is rarely observed.

It is well known that coordination polymers with a d10 configuration metal possess excellent luminescence property . Herein, the solid-state fluorescent property of compound 1 was investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in , upon excitation of these solid samples at λ ex =360nm, the intensely strong blue-fluorescent emission bands are observed at 455 and 505nm for 1. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480nm, the free Hatz ligand and PTA ligand present photoluminescence emissions at 325nm and 387nm, respectively, according to the reported literature . Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may be tentatively attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transition (MLCT) and/or ligand-to-metal charge transition(LMCT), which has been observed in other tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymers . Along with the high thermal stability and insolubility in common inorganic or organic solvents, the emission in the blue region makes this compound a potential blue-light emitting material.

decomposition temperature.type: framework collapses corresponding to the removal of the organic atz and PTA ligands
